one_reviews_text: Don't let anyone tell you the rift or rift s is better than this for PC.. this is the best bang for the buck and the image quality and refresh rate is superior to both the rift and rift s. I haven't had tracking issues once and I've been playing wirelessly via virtual desktop exclusively because airlink kinda sucks.. and the link cable I bought randomly disconnects but virtual desktop works flawlessly and I don't notice any latency, then again I'm playing 3 feet from the router.. the stock headband sucks as many others have mentioned as well as the face pad so I upgraded both. The speakers are okay, they're not as bad as everyone makes them out to be but I will be installing a headphone mod on mine. One issue I have is that sometimes the software will freeze when I try to multi task, responding to a Facebook message while streaming my PC for example but a reboot fixes it.. still annoying though. I can't review the all in one aspect of this headset because I use it exclusively for PC VR
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 19 October 2021
review_title: 10x better than the rift cv1 for PCVR

one_reviews_text: I purchased this for my son for Christmas. He was overjoyed and excited. As he started to try to install it to his  nitro gaming laptop he found that this particular device did not have the graphics card needed to be present to support this device. He was on customer support for over an hour they tried several things we wound up having to return it. My son is heartbroken and I am very angry. If you go on the site there is literally a listing of 6 to 10 laptops and computers that are not compatible with this gaming device. Knowing this The designers have yet to fix this problem since it’s release in 2018 and update their product! I think that they should make it apparent to the consumer that there are certain needs to support this accessory before they purchase it and break their kids heart on Christmas!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 December 2021
review_title: Is NOT supported by ALL computers

one_reviews_text: Let me preface this by saying, I've never been a video game player, just not my thing. I got this for Christmas, and all I can say is...Wow. As a former ping-pong player in my youth, I decided to give the game a shot. It is so immersive, standing in the middle of the room with the table in front of you, it feels so real. It is so realistic that I keep finding myself wanting to lean on the table for certain shots, big mistake; you need to remind yourself that the environment isn't real. Moved on to golf. Once again, you are standing in the middle of the golf course with 360-degree views of the entire scene, it's incredible.  I've only had this a few days, but if what I've seen so far is any indication, I am a video game person. I just had to find the correct format. Love it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 January 2022

one_reviews_text: I love this, though I wish it were a bit wider for use with glasses, and I wish they sold replacement cushions for it more inexpensively as I am sweating. Otherwise, it's nearly perfect! This is a very polished experience.Wireless is super important. While I did get the pricey link cable for use with my PC, and I will be playing PC games on this headset, I underestimated how much better it is to be wireless. I will explore the Airline (wireless PC connection) too, but again using this with a PC adds a layer of complexity. If you want to use this by itself for a quick session, that's where it really shines as it's easy to put on and go.While Oculus is owned by Facebook, and they're begging for government regulation, AND the default sharing settings are too leaky for my taste, I am willing to compromise. I see this as my first, but not last, VR system. I will upgrade in a few years as technology improves, and will consider a different company's platform then. But for now this is a great way to try out VR.The apps are well done and include usual video apps from youtube, amazon prime, and netflix. I am using a few inexpensive games, mostly for fitness and that's working well. You can use transparency mode to set up a virtual safe zone so you can move freely and it'll let you know if you are going out of it. Just very impressive how well it all works.With regard to glasses, I use an older pair that are narrow and fit better. I don't use the included silicone face pad cover because that does get caught on the smaller glasses and that's not good. So, if it's sweaty I detach the face pad and clean it...but I foresee that it won't last forever. Replacements seem to be pricy but I will also experiment with aftermarket ones. A side benefit to this being such a big selling product is that there are numerous third party accessories for it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 9 January 2022
review_title: Excellent intro to VR at a great price and wireless

one_reviews_text: Great headset, the kids' love it but nowhere in the product description does it mention it requires a Facebook account so Mark Zuckerberg can data mine your personal information.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 11 October 2021

one_reviews_text: I was an early adopter of PSVR.  Over the years I played it less and less, just because it was a hassle to set up.  Not that it was hard, just that it was annoying.The fact that Quest 2 is standalone and no wires is EXACTLY why it's so amazing.  I've had it for nearly 2 months now and I play it every day.  Sometimes multiple times a day.I use it for workouts, which I didn't know was even a thing.  If I can be tricked into physical activity, great!I also having been using Virtual Desktop to tap into my PC so I can run Steam VR.  It works perfectly, all wireless.  128GB is plenty of space if you are debating.Here's an example of a major improvement.  My daughter would use PSVR and I would need to be near to make sure she wouldn't hit the TV or something and have to help her not get tangled up with the cord.  Now with Oculus I set up a Guardian so she can clearly see the invisible walls I set for her and no longer need to untangle her from cords.  You can also stream to a TV using Chromecast or the phone app so you can see what the user is seeing.  The app also gives you control to help them launch games or reset their position.  These improvements are HUGE!I've been BLOWN AWAY how much better the Quest 2 is over older VR headsets, especially PSVR.  Everything looks better and plays with better controls.  I can't see this going down the same road with PSVR where I stop using it, it's just really really good.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 24 January 2022
review_title: This is the VR headset EVERYONE needs

one_reviews_text: The biggest drawback with this headset is the weak USB port and other charging issues. It doesn't take much pressure to break that USB port and once you break it, u might as well throw the whole headset away because there is absolutely no way to repair or replace it. Check the internet for all of the complaints concerning the headset's charging issues and you'll see what I mean. My headset lasted for about 2 months and with the continuous charging, eventually the port became weak and broke and the cable started melting the headset housing around the USB port to the point that it completely stopped charging. Never again will I buy another Oculus headset. A waste of $300.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 December 2021
review_title: Don't waste your money...wait for something more reliable.

one_reviews_text: Likes:-Games are good! Plenty to choose from.-Audio is ok. You can enable Bluetooth earbuds/headphones-VR is in par with Playstation VR but better since you can create a safe space (guardian) and walk around in VR vice just sitting or standing with PSVR.-Quality is good. Combination of plastic and elastics. Not heavy and can play for 3hrs with minimum neck fatigue.-Sickness? Not that bad depending on game/video. For the most part I only felt sick when playing seated. Watching videos didn’t make me sick at all. Now for the bad.-Facebook: Not so much of a bad but more of a why. Seems a bit sketchy having a system with cameras all around watching your home as you traverse on a VR environment. Guardian safe zone? More like now I know your living space and where you spend most the time. Also thanks for the cool interior pics of your house.- Price: I can see myself playing this for a little bit, not as often as my home console. Not that I will stop playing it, but more like not worth $299.99 playing every day type. FYI I got the $200 discount from the Amazon credit card so I only payed $109.00ish.-Head Strap: By far the worst thing this VR headset has. Not only is it uncomfortable but seems like it will break anytime in the near future. Everything points to OCULUS wants you to buy their premium strap.-Battery life: Depending on use you can squeeze like 2.5-3 tops on hours of playtime. This is if you are moderate with what you got turned on and turn it fully off when not in use.I will keep updating this review as time goes by as we all know this was a hot XMas present in 2021. Pandemic and all everyone is down to do some indoor travel a la VR Mode.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 28 December 2021
review_title: You’re missing out. 3hrs of Fun Per Charge.

one_reviews_text: This was purchased as a Christmas gift for my 12yo daughter. It is a huge hit, not only for her, but her Dad and I have had a blast on it also! Once you have the headset on it feels like you are really in the VR game you are playing. As a parent I like you set perimeters of the room you are playing in and once you leave the set perimeters the game pauses and you can see where you are in the room. This is a great safety feature, especially if you are playing in a room with a lot of obstacles or stairs. Set up was easy, we did have to set up a Facebook account, which I wasn't thrilled about. But, once it is set up it is managed from the VR headset or the app. She has had a blast playing gorilla tag with a couple of her school friends that got the Oculus as well.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 19 January 2022

one_reviews_text: Maybe it's because I live in a studio apartment with my elderly, dementia parent. Maybe it's because I'm not interested in getting outside as much due to covid. Or maybe it's inflation. Whatever the reason or excuse, I LOVE the escape these glasses give me.It's addictive!To feel snuggly, alone, and transported is SOO AWESOME!I not only visit other countries, but I love going under water, or overhead with a drone sky-view of the world.I love the feel of the rollercoaster rides. So funny how our minds can cause physical reactions. Love it! Don't get that belly-drop feel, any more - belly's too fat - but I do get a wonderful dizzy feel when descending down the rollercoaster.Watching TV or Prime/Netflix is synonymous to being in my own media room, curled up and cozy.I haven't played any games yet.As interested as I am in AI, the introduction robot creeped me the heck out because it looked me in my eyes and danced with me, responded to my dance movements. How is that possible? Or is that a real human, drawn to look like a colorful stick figure? Rushed through that and never returned.Very meditative. You will fall asleep with this on, several times.I wait till my parent is sleep then I indulge, but since she likes to compete with me - once again proving how young she really is (sigh), I only use once every two weeks. At the end of the day, too tired to put on knowing I'd be snoring within seconds.You can use with Bluetooth or plugin headset, too.I've decided to gift one to someone everyone every year.Enjoy!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 11 December 2021
review_title: I'm Afraid To Post A Review. Why? Because I Enjoy It Too Much!

one_reviews_text: This unit seems to be very glitchy. I tried hooking it up to my PC and tried it solo. Games that require "hand motion" detect ghost controllers no matter how far away I put the real ones(even put them outside in the car trunk.) When I am hooked to my Gaming PC via airlink, it starts off great but then gets really glitchy within minutes.  The virtual desktop and VR navigation seems to disappear and reappear out of reach...at will. Also, the Oculus Store is inaccessible then it's accessible...then inaccessible again only to be accessible for another brief window only to be inaccessible yet again...you get the idea.My PC is running at around 12% maximum disk use and 110-120 processes. I am running a 10th gen i9 with a dedicated video card and 32gb of RAM...so, if it's not going to work airlinked because my hardware isn't up to snuff then it should not be listed that it's wirelessly PC compatible at all.I ordered a 10ft ultra high speed USB C to USB C data cable to see if it works better when physically tethered. The unit comes with what seems like an intentionally short USB C charging cable in an attempt to sell their way overpriced 10 ft cable. So...we'll see in a few days when the cable arrives.On a side note, why in the world would the manufacturer's design include a power button right underneath the strap? Every time a player tries to physically adjust the headset they unintentionally close everything out only to reopen and find everything aggravatingly rearranged.I thoroughly expected to see my daughter using the headset and sailing through virtual worlds on Christmas morning and not getting so frustrated that she gave up even trying to use it.Maybe my unit is defective. If it's the same way after the new cable arrives then I intend to ask for either a refund or a working replacement.EDIT: The main reason we bought this VR setup was for Roblox VR. The high speed cable came in and VOILA! the glitchy PC connection is no more. The only issue now seems to be that we have to uninstall the headset, restart the PC and reinstall the Quest 2 headset every time we want to use it tethered. However, my daughter loves the Roblox VR play and says it rocks...so, looks like we're going to keep the unit.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 December 2021

one_reviews_text: What they don't tell you about the Quest 2 is that its more narrower than the previous headsets meaning that you have to force your glasses into it which doesn't provide for a very pleasant experience as the glasses dig into the side of your head, you could buy $200 VR lenses (if you have bad vision like me) which at that point I would rather like to track down a Rift S instead.Avoid if you have glasses unless you can justify buying the lenses as well, ontop of a headstrap that should have been included and a 3rd party oculus link cable.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 October 2021

one_reviews_text: This was a big purchase for us and wow, was it worth it.  We use it primarily for the Supernatural exercise program (requires a subscription).  If you want an incredibly fun -- positively addictive, really -- way of getting your cardio and building some muscle, this is for you.  Being new to VR, I was concerned that the Oculus setup would be difficult and that there would be a steep learning curve.  Nope.  The Oculus takes you through everything you need to do seamlessly.  We have upgraded the head strap and added grip covers (both from Kiwi) as they help keep everything in place when you are moving around as much as we are in Supernatural.  For more stationary apps, the stock setup should be fine.  One thing to be aware of if you wear glasses -- smaller frames fit fine but larger frames will get squished.  Considering the cost of eyeglasses, this is a definite consideration.  We both got prescription VR Wave lenses that fit in the Oculus and this solves that problem (about $100 each and they work amazingly well, even with strong prescriptions.)  So if you are going to just be playing fairly stationary games and don't need glasses, this $300 expenditure will probably be it.  If you want to do what we do, or wear glasses, expect to be spending a bit/lot more.  Would we buy it again?  Absolutely.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 February 2022

one_reviews_text: Very impressed by the meta quest 2 graphics, sound, ease of use navigating is really pretty much straight forward just follow prompts and you're good to go. For a VR headset you really do get a lot of value for your money. Not to mention it's a stand alone headset, meaning no need to have your headset wired to a PC (unless you still wanna do it that way, cause you can using a link cable) but why would you want to do that? Personally I use AirLink and it works GREAT! Bringing my family of gamers together and moving is just one of the many benefits this has provided for us and with all the news surrounding the meta verse, it seems we are just starting and will only get better moving forward. 1 potentially HUGE downside for some... As of writing this review you NEED a Facebook account in order to set up your quest 2 VR headset. Fingers crossed this will be removed as a requirement in the near future. But it is still a lot of fun.

one_reviews_text: I got this for my 9 yr old son for his Christmas gift. And while I know Oculus is affiliated with Meta/Facebook, I don’t like the fact that in order to use the toy - you HAVE to have an active Facebook account. Not a throw away account like I wanted to set up.While my son loves the oculus, I find the cost of the games you can buy to be super expensive. So it makes the ability to get him a variety of games difficult. $30 on average is a tough pill to swallow after paying $300 for the device.But my biggest gripe is having to have a Facebook account to have access to the device. I believe they’re going to change it. I still hate it cause I hate Facebook.You should have an option to set up access without having Facebook. Period.Take that away? The Oculus is a good purchase since my son loves it.

one_reviews_text: Compared to my original quest, this one is much faster, lighter, and has more memory space. I would recommend getting this or upgrading to it. I would also recommend being careful with it as the strips are white fabric and can be stained easily.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 December 2021

one_reviews_text: I was skeptical, but my son wanted one. It is way better than you might think. I ended up getting one for myself. I can play games like mini golf with my son when he is at his mothers house. I use it mainly for exercise (supernatural) on which I am totally hooked. Best exercise innovation in a decade without a doubt. It is just so fun you don’t feel hardly any effort of getting your heart rate up to a level for aerobic fitness. In fact my main issue has been over exercising with it, even though I am pretty fit. I also use it for meditation. There are a number of apps for that. None are perfect but right now Tripp is the best. While the meditation apps don’t yet live up to the incredible production value of supernatural, nonetheless I am very impressed at how the immersive nature of VR helps shift me into a more meditative state much more rapidly and with much less effort than standard meditation - which I am quite experienced at. In summary, this is absolutely great value, great for connecting with friends and family members in multiplayer games, and most of all an excellent wellness tool for exercise and meditation. It definitely isn’t just for kids.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 12 May 2022
review_title: You will be surprised how good it is

one_reviews_text: I've always wanted to get into Virtual Reality and the Quest 2 gave me a chance. The Quest 2 has helped me with covid restrictions as I'm a people person and being an adult with high functioning autism I can't wear face masks due to sensory issues, I can't get pixels sick or ketch anything from them. Being a furry I've always wanted a fursuit but due to my sensory issues I couldn't afford nor wear one. For some reason with the Quest 2 and VRChat I can finally enjoy my Virtual Reality life and real life.The Quest 2 has definitely helped make me a better person as I've been able to work with my communications skills and not be so shy around large groups of people. From a gaming aspect  I love the freedom of being wireless to play Beat Saber or any other game away from home the best part is if you have mobile hotspot and your game needs internet you can use your hotspot on your smartphone to play away from home. Always play in a shady preferably covered spot with the Gardian on. If it's to bright it can't track the hand controllers and could damage the Quest 2 cameras and burn the screen.I've done alot of research on the Quest 2 before I spent the money. The price point to get into VR with the Quest 2 was great compared to pc only based VR heasets which also need a high power gaming PC to work.. The Quest 2 is completely  standalone it absolutely does not need a PC to use it, it does require a Facebook account to use.The ability for the Quest 2 to be used with a PC to play PC based VR games with or without the Oculus link cable. Definitely love it being stand alone and the  wireless ability is the best. I definitely recommend getting a different headstrap though the one that comes with it can be painful to the back of your head due to the plastic adjustment things on the back of the strap.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 14 January 2022

one_reviews_text: I bought this expecting to connect to my Oculus account and share my library of compatible games I purchased for my Rift through the link cable. But since my Oculus account is tied to a different email address than my Facebook account that has been a nightmare sorting out. After communicating with Oculus Support for a few hours they have stopped responding and my account is not working still. It has been well over 8 hours since any communication from them. I wish Facebook didn't ruin Oculus, but now I guess I can move onto another platform such as HTC after I make the return.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 November 2021

one_reviews_text: Man, ready player one? Like I’m there once we get there ykno? And I know we’re not going to be there anytime soon but I really been wanting to try out VR; so I decided to cop one. I’d recommend, if you don’t already use VR and know your eye distance to get an app that does, because positioning this is key to a great experience.I gave it 3 stars because of the system setup between this and oculus on pc(it being two different entities) and well, maneuvering through the menu when you’re at the main menu is really laggy and choppy(I’m on 1Gbps connection) games get laggy too, it’s just overall pretty laggy and booting up after having it for like over a month now(and turning completely off after each use) it’s REALLY slow and then once in I have to wait, and wait, and wait until I can turn guardian back on because surprise it can’t be found and so like by the time I’m actually able to launch and play a game from the time I turn it on, I would say legit a 10 minute ordeal. It’s cool tho, and some games are legit, so I mean I’m only here to write this and let y’all know, I still will play it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 28 September 2021

one_reviews_text: I was so excited to grab this when it was on sale during Black Friday.As soon as I got it, I downloaded all of the free games as well as the sideloaded games. It was such a cool experience to be able to put a headset on and become a soldier, shooting and reloading realistically with the controllers.. playing Star Wars.. you already know what I mean.But I noticed about a month of 1 hour play per day, I would take off the headset, look at my hands, and my brain would "lag" almost and make me feel like I was looking at my VR hands. This got progressively worse (my brain would take longer and longer to "reset"). And with Zuckerberg asking churches to join VR, businesses, I see this as a sly "harmless" way that he is pushing his agenda... nothing good can come from messing with your brain/mind to the point where it gets confused if it's reality or VR- and who's to say we're not already in a simulation??
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 April 2022

one_reviews_text: Was there a Quest or a Quest 1? I don't think so. Why did FB/Meta start at 2? I have no idea. Maybe there was a Quest 1 and it ended up on the scrapheap for some reason and we never saw it.Anyway, the BIG NEWS with the Quest 2 is that you no longer need to hook up to a laptop/PC and so no longer need an expensive graphics card. The Oculus Rift cost about the same if a bit more than the Quest 2, but to operate it, you needed a graphics card that would set you back at least several hundred dollars. Worse than that, though, that required you to have a higher end PC, so instead of, say, a $500 Dell Inspiron, you were looking at having to have, say, a $2,000 Dell XPS. That was a major roadblock to mass availability of VR that FB/Meta took away by introducing the Quest 2 and putting the Rift out to pasture.Now that all sounds very 5 stars, and maybe it should be, so why am I only giving 4 stars?1. It's not as cool as I thought it'd be and I don't use it as much as I thought I would. The games/apps cost between $9.99 and $39.99, from what I've seen, but even the most popular game, Beat Saber for $29.99, which is kind of like Dance Dance Revolution (DDR) but with a light saber, isn't that cool, even if on paper it sounds cool. It's not bad, just kinda meh.2. I don't know if it's my head or my eye placement or what, but I have a real issue with eyes strain using it and, most of all, with getting double vision I can't resolve no matter what I do, namely repositioning the headset and adjusting how far apart lenses inside are. Now, I do wear glasses and thought it might've been because of that and because of the spacer for glasses wearers provided with the Quest 2 to allow extra room inside the headset for glasses, so since I can see OK without glasses, no like I'm blind or anything, I tried taking that spacer out and going without glasses, same thing. For whatever reason, I can see just as well without my glasses in the headset, so that's good, but the issue of eye strain and occasional double vision that I can't resolve is exactly the same.3. The spacer for eyeglasses leaves a small open space or gap between the spacer and the body of the Quest 2 along the nose such that if you glance down with your eyes, you can see outside, see light, and even when you don't, it lets outside light in, so that's poorly designed.4. You need a fairly large open space of floor with absolutely nothing on it or anything next to it, like walls, stuff on counters, shelves, etc. You can play with a smaller space, but you're constantly getting alerted by a big wall of plus signs that you're reaching the edge of your safe space. Now, one thing that's cool is if you leave the space, cross that wall of plus signs, you no longer see the game but get a black and white video feed of what's in front of you, of your surroundings, kinda like looking at your home through a low-res black and white security camera. Now, I do have just barely enough space, but the problem I run into is that you actually need a somewhat larger space since gameplay will often result in your arms that space, so if you've outlined a safe space or play area that's big enough but there's a counter, table, shelf, whatever not in it but right next to it, you will can find your hand knocking into whatever's on that counter, table, shelf, whatever and maybe knocking it off or over or whatever, so it seems like the easy solution for people who don't have big open areas of flat floorspace with nothing surrounding it in their homes would be to play it outside, which brings me to my next point...5. You can't play it outside. Nowhere in any of the instructions does it say you can't use it outside, like it literally won't work outside, so when I tried to use it outside, I thought it had broken. The headset has sensors all over it that must use the walls and ceiling to bounce off of, so when there are no walls or ceiling, it literally freaks out. The controllers work, sort of, but not really. Instead of seeing them in your hands, like you normally can with the headset on, you'll see the controllers 10 or 15 feet away all on top of each other, and you use the menu buttons and fire buttons, but you can't aim, or can only sort of aim because it thinks the hand controllers are 10 or 15 feet away and not positioned like you have them positioned. Now, it seems like with games like Pokemon Go and with so many people not having the rather large amount of space needed to use the Quest 2 that outside wood be a perfect solution, like in a park or in my backyard or in my driveway. When I googled it, I found out that my Quest 2 wasn't broken, but what I was reading was spinning it to be like it didn't work on purpose outside for my safety and not that it's a shortcoming of the Quest 2, which is what it totally is. One interesting thing that I did learn, though, is that the magnifying lenses in the Quest 2 should never be left in direct sunlight, not outside nor inside on a windowsill because if direct sunlight hits it, the sunlight hitting it will be like sunlight hitting a magnifying glass, only it'll focus it on the display screen inside and burn through it lickety-split. So that's A CRITICALLY IMPORTANT THING TO KNOW THAT'S NEVER MENTIONED IN THE MATERIAL YOU GET WITH THE QUEST 2 WHEN YOU BUY IT.Now that all may make it sound WORSE than it is. Those are my criticisms. Still, it's a pretty dang cool piece of tech, especially for the price. It's just not what I thought it'd be, so I'm going to be giving mine to my nephew.ANOTHER IMPORTANT PIECE OF INFORMATION: 64GB for $100 less vs. 128GB for $100 moreI spent the extra $100 and bought the 128GB one because I didn't want it going obsolete or running short on memory or whatever. If I had it to do all over again, I'd have saved myself the hundred bucks and bought the 64GB one, not because I'm giving it away but because there's no way you'd ever use 64GB, much less 128GB.What the storage is for isn't RAM, so it has no effect on performance, but is strictly for storing games, file storage. Each game, though, is only about 1GB, so before you'd ever use up 64GB, you'd have to have more than 60 apps/games on there. Setting aside that's around $1,800 in apps/games and just a crazy amount in my mind, even if you are that heavy a user and do have that much stuff, it doesn't matter because you can use a USB cable and put games you're not using or don't plan to use on a library that can store them on an app or even through a cell phone app on a cloud, so you'd only ever actually need more than 64GB and so pay the extra $100 for the 128GB version is if you actually want to have access to 60 to 120 games and apps all at the same time without having to swap games/apps out with others in your library. Now, you may be thinking of future-proofing, that there will come a time when the games/apps are 2GB or 3GB or 5GB or whatever and so don't want to be caught short, but you won't be, or you will be, but it won't matter. The reason games/apps are only around 1GB each is going much bigger than that would push or exceed the limits of the Quest 2's processors and internal RAM. That means that when down the road games/apps grow much larger than what they are now, it'll be time to upgrade from the Quest 2 to whatever's next. There's no avoiding that by spending an extra $100 for 128GB of onboard storage instead of 64GB. Now, when the Quest 2 first came out last year, it came out with only 32GB at the same price it is now with 64GB. 32GB wasn't enough storage, so FB/Meta quickly remedied that by making a 64GB for $100 more, but then it obsoleted the 32GB version and dropped the price of the 64GB to the same as what the 32GB one had been. FB/Meta then added the 128GB option because of people demanding it after panicking from the 32GB one not being enough that they thought 64GB wouldn't be either or soon wouldn't be. But it's totally unnecessary and a waste of $100. If you don't believe me, just research it for yourself. EVERYONE says so, and having lived it myself now, I fully agree.SAVE YOURSELF $100 AND BUY THE 64GB QUEST 2......BECAUSE YOU WILL ALMOST CERTAINLY NEVER EVER USE UP EVEN THE 64GB, MUCH LESS EVER NEED 128GB, AND IF YOU SOMEHOW WOULD EVER HAVE MORE THAN 64GB IN APPS/GAMES, YOU CAN SIMPLY STORE EXCESS LESSER USED APPS ON ANOTHER DEVICE/CLOUD THAT YOU CAN REDOWNLOAD THEM FROM SHOULD YOU EVER WANT THEM ONBOARD YOUR QUEST 2 AGAIN LATER, BECAUSE THAT 64GB IS JUST ONBOARD STORAGE CAPACITY, NOT TOTAL STORAGE CAPACITY, WHICH WITH A PC/CLOUD, SKY'S THE LIMIT.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 May 2022
review_title: Quest 2 requires no graphics card in your PC or even a PC at all, unlike its predecessor the Rift!

one_reviews_text: So, I'm new to this VR equipment and I've used this for about 2 months now and I must say I am astonished by how awesome it is. Great amount of content on the oculus store and so much fun for everyone.There are several things I noticed that got a little irritating at first so I am writing this to let others know to save them from the frustration.- If you are new to this type of experience, you will unavoidably feel motion sickness. It was hard for me to get through at first but after a few days or attempts of playing, I adapted to it pretty well to where it does not bother me anymore. Best thing to do is to make sure you have a way to cool yourself down while  you are using it (perhaps a fan) and take frequent breaks.- If you have bangs, be sure to move them out the way of your forehead. It interferes with the sensor. Often the screen would turn black in the middle of gameplay and I would readjust the headset only to realize it was my hair being in the way of the sensor that would cause the screen to go black.- When creating a guardian, I emphasize creating a GOOD play space because there are several times where I have hit something even if wasn't inside the play space. You'll be warned about stepping out of your boundary but not if any object is in the way.-The controllers comes with AA batteries but unfortunately you would have to replace them at some point. There is a rechargeable product that is pretty expensive so my method of recharging the controllers is through the use of rechargeable batteries.-From what I know, you need to play in the light, as there is no way the VR would be able to detect your surrounding if lights were off.There are things I have noticed and I hope to whoever read this find this information useful.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 15 October 2021

one_reviews_text: I 10000% Second guessed buying this for my 28 year old boyfriends b day because I seen a lot of reviews that where not the best, I had one family friend get it and very highly recommended it so I did it, Don’t buy this expecting free games on games, This is an amazing experience but one that cost money almost every hood app cost from $10-$50 some games are better than others, they also have workout apps mini gulf shooting and fighting games traveling simulators like endless life and it’s just amazing to have in your living room looking and feeling like your in a whole other world is so crazy ! Please get this I recommend this BIGTIME !
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 March 2022

one_reviews_text: For years I had contemplated a VR headset, but was hesitant.  I had not know anyone else who owned one, so I had no word of mouth to go off of.  I finally bit the bullet and gave this a try.From moment one, I was very impressed with the quality of the device and the VR environment.  Setting up an area was simple, and helped keep me safe. To those who are not aware, the device has you set up a square or circle area to play in.  You set it up with the device, in an area free and clear of obstacles.  Any time you step out of the area, you can literally see through the device into the world outside the VR headset (in black and white), letting you know you are outside the safe zone, and showing you where you are physically so you don't hurt yourself.  I had NO idea that was a feature, and it is truly awesome that this is available as a safety feature.  No walking into walls or into coffee tables!The VR world itself is pretty impressive.  There are a few tutorials you can run through to learn how to operate in the world.  There are ways you can "Pick up items" using the controllers, that felt weird at first, but became second nature.  You can even set it up so that you can use your actual hands and fingers to navigate and select items, free from the controllers.There are a few games you can play for free, as well as a few free videos that will take you to places you never thought possible.  Many of the games for purchase are under $30.You can set up your netflix or amazon prime, and watch your favorites in the VR world.On the whole, I am extremely impressed with the Oculus Quest.  I am already planning on purchasing more to give as gifts, so that I can interact with friends and family in the VR world.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 6 April 2022

You can't call customer support, you can only email or chat and they don't help.  They keep asking for the same stuff over and over and I keep sending it and getting nowhere.  It's been going on for about two weeks now.  Very expensive piece of junk.

one_reviews_text: Order a different strap while you're at it. The original is pathetic and uncomfortable. Downloading was slow and updates maddening with our old provider, but most games can be played solo without the connection after download.Otherwise, wow! I even watch Netflix on it while dh is watching sports. There's lots of games and things to do (ping pong, racquet ball type game, boxing, Adventure games...). The best part is playing a game with family who lives 1800 miles away. It's like being in the same room as we laugh, talk, and play.THREE MONTHS LATERI spend WAY too much time on VR. The headset still looks like new, even though I use it daily. I am very careful with it. One evening it wouldn't turn on. Checked original order to look for warranty info (3 months and a few days after purchase) and used the link for "Included Amazon Support." Entered phone number, got a call in just a couple minutes. The person was a bit difficult to understand, but for the most part sounded like he was listening rather than just reading/repeating prepared script. I'm guessing there is no specific product knowledge, but after several attempts to revive unit (black screen) a return was arranged and a new headset is due to arrive in 4 days. I will check new box for warranty info. to be sure the next one doesn't wait until expired. If I have any issues downloading all the purchased apps, I'll append this review.Yes there are ways the headset could have been better. It is front heavy and it's difficult to imagine they couldn't do better, but that's probably part of planned obsolescence. The original set up did not flow intuitively, and ultimately did not get the referral credit. I don't like having fb linked, but use the various settings so it isn't telling everyone when I'm playing nor reporting to my wall. I don't like having limited sources for purchasing games, but plenty of folks seem to think that's ok with apple. With all it's shortcomings, I still highly recommend this. I've never been "a gamer" so perhaps my expectations are different from those that find this system intolerable. But I've "met" some great folks on line (some not so great too), had fun with family, and really enjoy the system.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 February 2022
review_title: play and talk with family miles away

one_reviews_text: I picked this up for my teenage son as a Christmas present. I was a bit concerned about the internet connection, since we live very rural and have only a very, very slow connection. But this works without a problem.The headset is, thanks to the straps, adjustable to a wide range of head sizes. It doesn't pinch the hair or rub or feel uncomfortable. The viewer fits around my younger daughter's head all the way up to my husband's very large one. There is a built-in cushion around the area it rests on the face, which keeps it from rubbing or irritating. The nose area, unfortunately, isn't nearly as 'all fitting' and is rather large. My son does find it sometimes distracting, since he can glimpse a tiny bit of the 'real' world when glancing down. There is also an extra accessories which is placed in the headset for those who wear glasses. I've tried it with and without this extra piece, but didn't have trouble with my glasses either way. The handheld controllers are comfortable in the hand, have buttons which are easy to reach, and work very well. These do have wrist straps, which work very well, too.On to the games and usage! I'm not tech-savvy, so things have to be pretty basic for me to use them. This headset is no problem. It came mostly charged and ready to go. It's pretty self-explanatory with the menus easy to see and use when the visor is on. It took about 2 hours for the installation to download and install...but that's thanks to our very, very, very slow connection. And we found that fast (so that tells you how quick it'd be on 'normal' connections). It took a bit to flip through all of the menu options and included apps to see what is there and what not. We did need to download the games, but this was no problem. There are free ones and variously priced ones, giving something for every direction and budget. Once downloaded, the games work easily with or without internet connection (depending on the game, I assume). We got the basic memory one and it has more than enough space for us.The headset battery usage lasts about 2 to 4 hours, but this depends on what games are being played as well as the screen brightness and such. So, it can vary. The hand controllers, of course, hold longer, but believe it or not, these are NOT rechargeable. They use standard AA.Clear some room space when using this. It does have an awesome mapping out application, which the kids loved to use and roam through the house with. And the games to have the player 'draw' the borders first. Watch flailing arms, though (we did have some accidental whacking of innocent family members going on). It is fun. Tons of fun. Some of my relatives, who tried it out for a few minutes because...who wouldn't?...did experience a bit of a headache after 5 or so minutes of play or had a bit of dizziness. I didn't have a problem nor do my kids, though.I'm glad we picked this up, one for both of my kids at home, and they do play together (they can chat through the headsets and such as well). Oh, and my son has streamed Netflix through it and said that it's an odd experience as well.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 28 December 2021

one_reviews_text: Great standalone set.  The older models 64 GB was a bit too small in storage.  This 128 GB is plenty of room to house a good number of games.  I currently have 75 GB free of 128, and have RE4, Saints and Sinners, Climb 2, Thrill of the Fight, All three Vaders, Wander, Brink, VR Fishing, and golf+ loaded.The Quest does take some getting used to.  I got nauseous the first time I used it for any length of time.  But eventually you get used to it.  Everything works as intended.  And the controllers are pretty accurate and responsive.  Headset isn't heavy to be uncomfortable.  But thank goodness the battery only lasts an hour or two, or you could be down the rabbit hole for a while and not even know it.Quest store though has a lot to be desired.  You really have to research games on your own.  Very few have trial versions where you can try a small portion to see if you like it.  The search for games is really basic in the store.  It seems they will really push certain games.  And it gets hard to navigate.  Really, in the store, you either know what you want and can search it, or good luck finding anything.  Unfortunately, this means you have to rely on third party review sites.  Which means they are recommending what they like, not what you may be looking for.  This really puts smaller and niche games at a disadvantage, as most of these review sites look at the same best games.Also the desktop program store and the store on the quest are the same, but different.  You have to watch out what you are buying, and make sure it's for the right product.  You can go to the Oculus store, and have only the Quest 2 as your device, and they will still bring up products for the Rift and Quest.  And if you accidentally buy them, you are SOL.  So it's best just to stick to the store on the Quest 2.  And as I said before, the Quest 2 has very few trials.  Most everything is buy to play.  And once you buy, there are no returns.The big plus for the desktop though is that if your PC can handle it.  For lack of a better term, you can stream a game onto your quest from the PC.  Controllers won't work, and you have to use the keyboard on most.  But I hear it transforms some desktop games.  And with recent updates, you can do it without tethering.Overall, despite a lot of quirks and issues.  It's been worth it.  VR still isn't where it should be.  But the Quest 2 is a big step in the right direction, in both affordability and what it gives you.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 December 2021

one_reviews_text: Pros:Cool new experience of the next big thing. It's exciting to just be apart of it.Speakers are amazing and you do not need headphones. I would like to see an add on subwoofer though in the future.Great entry price to get into this new universe.Cons:Headset is way too big, it's front heavy, the straps aren't comfortable. The size and weight needs to be majorly reduced. It's the same exact size as my first unit 7 years ago.Not many games, apps, and experiencesNo playable demos to try it before you buy it.No haptic feedback in the goggles.Image quality is the same as my unit 7 years ago, can still see pixelization in details, not crisp enough.Most apps have cartoonist graphics.  If you want xbox/Playstation VR you're only going to get super NES Mario Brothers VR for most all apps and games.  Haven't see. Unreal engine type graphics anywhere.Battery life is 1.5 hours which isn't very good.Nearly everything costs money. In the first 2 days I spent $150 on games and apps.  Good games are $40.Can't use Bluetooth headphones or surround speakers as the latency is too slow.No Color passthrough video, it's grainy black and white video.IOI opps I mean Facebook forces you to have a fb account and controls everything here. It's fine because it makes integration seemless, but I still don't like that you can't opt out even if you wanted to.Conclusion:There are any improvements that are needed but I still would recommend getting this.  Oculus pro cones out in May and Oculus 3 comes out in 2023. So if you are reading this before August 2022 than get this unit, if after that then wait for the next generation. It will be lighter and smaller for sure. In the future we'll look back at the quest 1 like how we look back at blackberry phones.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 8 January 2022
review_title: Cool new tech, but not quite there yet.

one_reviews_text: I was pretty excited to get the OQ2 after hearing about it.  I had high hopes of losing myself in the metaverse and immersing myself in other worlds.  Kind of hard to do when you're constantly annoyed because everything is out of focus.  I've tried with glasses, without glasses.  I've tried adjusting for IPD, pupillary distance (how far apart your eyes are) but with only 3 settings I can't get it right for me.  I constantly have to adjust the goggles on my face to get even just the center in focus.  The graphics are weak in most games, in fact most of the games feel and look like Wii games from almost 20 years ago.  Watching even the highest resolution videos are a disappointment too.  Very grainy and pixelated.I'm returning this.  Total disappointment.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 14 January 2022
review_title: Terrible Resolution, All But Center Out Of Focus, Disappointing!

one_reviews_text: A Fantastic idea to purchase for a early Christmas gift to my lady an myself. This is by far my favorite purchase of 2021 and play almost more then my PS5. Amazing games, some are a Lil off the wall but fun and affordable! I even bought some games and was able to return them full return back to my card. You will need to upgrade some parts to help with the experience but Amazon got tons of accessories for the oculus quest 2. Did get the 3 year warranty and we have kids so we supervise when using. Very pleased with my purchase.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 30 November 2021

one_reviews_text: So, there are two sides to this product. From a hardware standpoint, I really don't have any complaints. The headset is comfortable enough with one of the better adjustable head straps I've ever seen on any head-worn device. (I recommend wearing a cloth skullcap or even washcloth so that the strap isn't pulling on your hair (a baseball cap won't work), and the towel will collect sweat, although I've yet to sweat in it. There's a learning curve with the controllers, though it's not bad. Be careful, you could easily break them quickly, smashing them into each other, or punching into a wall or objects, though the guardian carrier does work effectively in keeping you from running into things once you set it up, so make sure you set it up properly. This product can NOT be operated in less than an 8ft square space. You may want to own a house with a dedicated room, or have some space in your apt. Don't expect to use this in an apt with no central open space. The audio isn't as good as some newer iphones, but its not bad either, however, I hope sending it out to a stereo is seamless. I have a feeling it won't be. Connecting to the internet was not a problem at all.My real issue is I don't feel the browsing of apps and functions is OPTIMAL considering how much fanfare Facebook is blowing about the metaverse. The nav took me a bit to get used to, but then it became fairly logical. The issue is some apps are much better at navigating than others. Having to boot out with the Oculus button varies app to app, and it almost never takes you back to the previous menu which you dove in from. The control console always shows up, but the menu of what you were in doesn't always. Case in point - the tv channel, which includes various travel VR scenes of Paris, Cairo etc. The Paris footage was great, if short, but I tried to boot out of Cairo, and the TV icon became visible, and I clicked on it, and I went right back into the video where I was, NOT to the previous menu of selections. I NEVER got back there, and ended up NOWHERE near where I started. Facebook needs to crack down on those apps not meeting the nav standards, but they prob don't want to lose previous content, which takes some effort to create, it is clear.You have to give this time. Some apps will disappoint, others will amaze, and there's no way to predict it, because this is a new sort of medium. The demos are often not adequate to be sure you want to pay for the app, and that can be a bummer, because if you don't like it, you just paid for zippo.For instance, one app claimed to be free, then dumped me into a big showroom where you have to buy your weapons. Other apps have demos good enough to make it clear buying the app will be worth it over time. Facebook should do more to demand adequate demos from developers.An app like Superhot is phenomenal and makes you happy you bought this. The demo gives you a taste of what the game about, and then the game seems like a good deal, and you've got a satisfying experience.  I HIGHLY recommend the ISS space experience downloads if you want to see what floating in orbit is like. It's quite astonishing. The travel experiences make you want to go to those places. The issue is if you don't get into the right apps, you might find yourself saying ho hum.The travel TV segments look great if a bit dated. The famous fitness program Supernatural instantly put me into a 14-day trial that will go straight into monthly payments if I don't cancel it. Can't you just show me the program for an hour without getting my payment info? This isn't your iphone where you know iOS is there to protect you. This is Facebook, and yeah, I have a bias towards Apple, and I'm here to tell them that this market is open to take away from Facebook, because they aren't doing it 100% optimally.Another problem I have is the utility VR programs that tap into desktop software I want to use that are more specialized work through Steam and the PC. I want the Quest 2 to interface with Apple, and that may not be happening.I'm not saying that VR isn't a stunning experience, and the physical side is really well figured out. It truly is, but the software side (as often is the case) could be tighter. This is Facebook, and they claim to own this space so they deserve more pointed criticism. The issue is also that VR is a somewhat new medium, so some patience is to be expected. It will take a few tries to get used to the basic operation, and then you can start assessing the apps. However, if you get dud apps before you get used to the operation, you may find it all overrated. I just think Facebook should match their introduction to the physical use of the headset to a good cross section of apps to bring you in further. Echo VR is another app that shows you the potential of the medium once you get into it. However, I'm not really about meeting up with people I don't know to play games. These apps should have single-player options by default. The VR environment instantly puts you into a space where you're making choices, and sometimes you don't like the choices the app you're in has made. You want to do something else.People complain about the interface of the accounts with Facebook. I wasn't crazy about it at first, but you can create multiple profiles under the main one, so it's not the end of the world. Of course, many of the settings have to be reentered from scratch, and so far the apps don't seem to cross across the accounts, so not sure if that's optimal.Also, literally ZERO apps come with the console. There are free apps, but you wouldn't know it, since how to find them is NOT immediately apparent (once again, squeezing your own customer instead of being their pal), some of which are more or less lying, and others which are highly boring. You would think Facebook would have the brains to greet new users into their wondrous world by just having a mainstay of 3 seamless good apps for everyone that got you feeling good about the console you just bought.So I give it 4 stars for setup of the headset itself, and 2 stars for not really introducing the user properly to a set of apps that shows them the power of the medium overall.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 10 January 2022
review_title: Torn in two directions at once....

one_reviews_text: Once we purchased the virtual gaming console my son was eager to add games to his account.  Well thats when everything went bad.We purchased gift cards to use for this purpose and as soon as he entered the card numbers the funds were used before he could click to purchase the games.  He had been robbed online!  Someone in AZ stole his gift cards!This happened not once, but twice.I contacted Oculus support online and after 3-days of sending them details, screenshots of the account, etc.  they told us to contact the bank. They did nothing!We lost $75 on their unsecured web site via the app.  They suck!Now, my 12 year son is so disappointed.  That was his money he earned helping family members over Xmas break.Think twice before purchasing this console it's more of a headache than what it's worth.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 February 2022
review_title: BEWARE!  Online game purchases are unsecured!

one_reviews_text: Maybe I got a defective HP headset but I had to constantly make micro adjustments and the eye's had to be lined up perfectly to not get a fuzzy image. Event then most of the surrounding lens was putting out fuzzy images. I would get stuck in VR Mode on my Desktop and after force closing anything related too VR It would still be there.I would have to force log to get control of my mouse back because the Hotkey would not work anymore after getting stuck like that. VR Editing mode didn't work at all in the Unreal Engine (I'm a developer), I would be far too high up and my controllers wouldn't work.I had nothing but trouble with that headset all around it was horrible.I decided to buy an Oculus Quest 2 and I absolutely do not like the fact that you 'Have to pair it with your phone'. I really dislike the fact that you absolutely have to log in to Facebook on your phone and pair it in order to use the headset. If it weren't for that I would give 5 stars. The instant I put it on Everything was crystal clear unlike the over priced bulky/heavy HP headset I had.I didn't have to adjust the lenses and I was surprised that people would say text is easier to read on the HP then the Quest because that doesn't seem to be the case in fact with the HP headset I had to be looking directly at something or it would be very fuzzy and out of focus and the Quest doesn't have that issue at all...it could be to the side and still come in clear.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 5 January 2022
review_title: Better lenses then my old HP headset

one_reviews_text: I began my VR journey 2 months ago. I did some research prior to purchasing of different VR headsets, and the Oculous Quest 2 seemed liked the logical winner. The price for refresh rates offered and the visual quality was a no brainer; I thought. Never-mind that Facebook is attached to it. So for one month I have had in my possession the Quest 2.I will outline my experience here as a PC Gamer, and I'll try to keep it brief. What it's going to come down to is the duration at which you game. I haven't tried VR in any AAA titles, first person shooters. My primary reason for entering VR was for the flight simulator DCS World, which does support VR, but is not really graphically optimized for either AMD nor Nvidia.I started with a 5700 XT graphics card - which you can have an OK VR experience with. Enters the cable issue. Now, there are a very limited number of cables manufactured that can meet the data requirements for the Quest 2, IF you choose not to buy Oculous's OFFICIAL $expensive cable. I tried a few - get the official cable. And I might note; you do want the official cable. Skip the thought you are going to have an amazing PC gaming experience over WiFi data.Problem 2: Powering the headset while gaming. Now that you have the official cable AND even though you have USB 3.1/Gen 1 or 2 TYPE A - You need a USB adapter for type C. There are only a couple produced that actually provide enough data throughput to have an OK VR experience.The duration: It really depends on how long you play. For an online flight sim where missions take hours for one mission - the battery dies. Then you have to disconnect from the online server, switch back to your monitor; it becomes a whole ordeal.The solution: A USB type C PCIe 3.0 x 16 adapter card. And there are only a few manufactured that can actually provide enough power to charge the Quest 2 as you game. StarTech is one of them sold here at amazon to save you some trouble. Now, comes the other problem. Do you have enough room with your graphics card air cooler to use your other PCIe x16 (whatever gen) slot? Fortunately I did, so I got the adapter card.This part has nothing to do with the Quest 2 itself...You are enjoying your VR experience so you lay down a chunk of change to amplify that with a new modern graphics card like a 3080. If you don't put a water block on it - you lose your ability to use your PCIe 16x adapter. Why? Because the air coolers are 2.5 to 2.7 card slot widths to cool it. So you buy a riser cable to use the adapter...see where I'm going with this?So, back to the original problem - providing power to the headset so it's actually useful. The crux is the battery. Over time it's not going to hold a charge and your ability to game in VR is going to be less and less. - unless that adapter card or your motherboard can actually power the headset. My motherboard isn't too ancient (z370).So you spent $ for whatever it costs now - for a price/pixel ratio that is great, but is actually hot garbage in terms of functionality. Power.  Then you spend more money $$$ on trying to provide a solution to the power problem. The visual clarity is good for VR. You can read text, make out dials etc. In the end it's meaningless.My final conclusion is what myself and other PC gamers should of done instead of trying to find a solution to Oculous's problem is save and buy a proper PC gaming VR headset.The End - Other specific functionality regarding the headset below.Tracking: For whatever reason it will lose tracking no matter if my room is lit or not.Data throughput: Using my USB 3.1 Type A connections with a usb to c adapter works ok and it does achieve the data throughput required for VR - the Quest 2 doesn't like it at all. I have experienced graphics deterioration and strange blinking during head turning movement. This is to the point of having to exit the game and restart the game itself or restart the Quest 2. This is using a GeForce 3080. The only good experience I have had graphically is using a Type C adapter card and the only slot that can provide ample throughput is perhaps a PCIe 3.0 16x slot.Controllers: "Where is the second controller - you must have it!" For the majority of VR things I use only one controller, including gaming. My primary game controllers are an xbox style controller for PC and HOTAS for flight sims. Quest 2 will be like "But where are MY controllers? They all must be active!" You will receive controller notifications and sometimes while watching a movie you will have your controller your NOT using pop up in the middle of the movie screen.The guardian: Quest 2, "Set your guardian! No, really set it again...hey can you set that guardian up!?" The guardian is your virtual to real world play area. I primarily use stationary. You will set it, then you will have to set it again and again.My final overall thoughts for the Quest 2 is that it's a toy. It's an entry into the VR arena. The software platform and overall experience is perhaps built for the general masses to experience VR. Your VR experience will be of quality, but with limited time.* Other problems- Since switching to the USB port on my motherboard after an hour or so of play the bottom half of the video (gaming) pixelates and corrupts. I have not found a solution to this.I have found an active usb cable with an external power source can keep the quest 2 charged while playing.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 March 2022
review_title: PC Gamers Beware; Review written for the Arm Chair Warriors

one_reviews_text: I really wanted to love this since my boyfriend has an occulus and loves it. For starters, the fit is not ideal. I found that it was blurry and really wasn’t clear regardless of where I positioned the headset or how I moved the lenses. Then I could still see through the nose to the floor because it’s so much larger than my face. On top of that, it was so heavy it just made the entire experience uncomfortable and not enjoyable. I gave two stars because I see a lot of promise with VR; just not this early in the game.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 November 2021
review_title: The fitting is cumbersome and heavy

one_reviews_text: Update: Facebook did refund my bundle purchased in error. They also have been very good at keeping in touch via email. It was still frustrating, but i do love VR.I received this as a birthday present. I have really enjoyed using it. However, when I tried to use it the second day, I was shown a screen that wanted me to log in. When I tried, it came up with an old email address which I don’t have access to anymore. It would not let me change the email address. It also allows one to login using Facebook However it would not accept my password. After conversations with three ‘support agents’, I gave up. Then, quite by accident, I discovered I could login using the iPad app. I had asked it I could use it to log in, but was ignored. Then, being an inexperienced user, I ordered a bundle of games. When I installed  the first of 3 I discovered that it needed me to be able to move around. So, since I had seen Oculus had a good refund policy, I tried to get a refund. The website denied my refund and said I could chat with an agent. When I got the agent online, he told me that they don’t refund bundles. I explained I was handicapped and confined to a chair. He said”most people research before buying”. That was not a very friendly response. My advice is to be aware that you are on your own. I’m 77 years old. One would think I would know better then to trust “Meta”, which now owns Oculus.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 25 December 2021
review_title: Support is terrible/ but they finally came thru

one_reviews_text: After putting in some time to read reviews on some top tech sites about the best VR headset to purchase, I made this purchase pretty enthusiastically. Fast-forward two days and I just as enthusiastically returned it.The graphics feel straight out of the Nintendo Wii era. The top-rated games are pixelated and give no sense of immersion. There's stuttering in the menu animations. The whole thing feels like the headset's hardware is struggling to run graphics from years ago. It feels buggy and incomplete and very dated.That being said, the controls are great and there are some really cool features that would make this an amazing unit if the hardware was amped up a bit. I love the ability to draw the boundaries of your playing area, and the "guardian" wall it projects to keep you safe while playing. I still can't figure out how it remembered the boundaries of my playing area in my living room after I turned the headset off and took it to another room before bringing it back.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 18 October 2021

one_reviews_text: EDIT #1- The first purchase was replaced in record time by Amazon... due to power failures.Our "NEW" unit performs as intended so far. As fads go, it will cost you considerably to operate.Valentines Day gift idea, for our "Straight A" student.. but Just another major distraction... at a high cost factor. New tech fad that will fade away like the rest.  Be prepared to buy the costly accessories that will enable your VR to operate efficiently.Biggest complaint so far,.. the Battery Life... / power failures.and for starters, have a major credit card ready to set up an account... on scam masters F'book or Twitt'r...  Just another GAME format to keep the young at heart spending time away from reality... while keeping money flying from pockets.If you MUST have one, Amazon prices are in line with the rest and you can return if faster if it fails right out of the box... since they have a know fail rate.after a week.... the battery is a BIG issue for us,... we've tried a back-up battery... and that does it's job but will not help matters..And so, It is going back to Amazon ASAP...What'A Let'Down....
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 23 February 2022
review_title: Oculus Quest 2 - 128 GB Virtual Reality Headset

one_reviews_text: So, lets get right to it. The battery life on these vr headsets don't last very long. Maybe, just maybe an hour of playtime before your battery is low and you have to charge it. And that depends on what you are playing or doing with the headset. I understand they are headsets, not meant to last long but, it be nice if they at least last 2 hours at most. Then I would mind the whole take of and recharge them.Onto the heat issue. These things get do get a little warm after a while. And they can get hot if you are playing a very active game where you are moving a lot. Would've been nice to have some sort of better cushions for where the headset meets your head at. Because the cushion/spacers that come with the headset are not good at all. Don't get me wrong they are semi comfortable, I will give them that but, besides the semi comfort part, they don't help with keeping your face cool. Might have to look into aftermarket cushions for that area. Maybe some cushions that have a cool gel inside of them. Maybe that'll work, maybe.Overall though, I am happy with my purchase as VR is getting more and more popular now an days. Oh, the price also for these are good especially since you have some high ends headsets out there that have the same components and visuals and such.Recommend getting this headset if your looking to start getting into VR. Unless you save up for a more pricier and high end VR headset.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 February 2022

one_reviews_text: I started my journey into VR with an Oculus Rift S, that had many issues, mostly with my cord, that costs more than half the price of the headset to replace since FB stopped supporting the Rift S. When I bought this unit I was, for legitimate reasons, worried I might experience some issues. I did not. The Quest 2 runs PCVR better than my Rift S did, and it can also run games on it's own without my PC. As I do have a PC I opted for the lower gb version, since every game I own is off of steam for the most part. I will say that the stock strapping this comes with is some sort of miracle of modern science, the fact that it holds so tight with such a basic snap-on connection is crazy, but that strap is garbage. I'd recommend buying an upgraded halo for the Quest 2 immediately.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 18 February 2022

one_reviews_text: I love this headset. I purchased it specifically to use Supernatural, and it's totally worth, even it if that's all you do with it. I'm finding other apps that I enjoy also. Initially I had a problem with the guardian tracking; however, after an update, it seems to have mostly corrected itself. The "mostly" is why I'm only giving it 4 stars instead of 5. To be fair, I contacted Oculus support directly and they were very helpful and responsive and were going to allow me to send it back. There's a lot of reasons to me why that was a little scary and very inconvenient, but mostly because I'm paying for some subscriptions and the fear of how long it would take to get a replacement. I tested it out for a while before thinking I would send it back, but it has kept working. So, I'm keeping it. Hoping it doesn't die, now that I've missed my return window, but so far so good and it's absolutely worth it. Especially if you're like me and sit at a desk ALL day and want to exercise without anyone seeing you (or leaving your house).
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 April 2022

one_reviews_text: **UPDATE** I requested a new one on Jan 18th, finally received the replacement on Jan 26th.It would have been much easier and faster to have originally purchased from the Oculus store.As of right now: delivered this morning 730 unboxed and charged, 10am first start: controllers would not track properly.  Set up through oculus app then it updated and restarted. Immediately after restart the screen tracking was all over the place rendering it useless.  After an hour in a chat window with oculus support we determined it was DOA. Replacement ordered now to wait 10-11 days for the "prime shipping" to get it here. Bonus though, if the new one works i got 15 bucks from oculus for my troubles and btw they offered a replacement too.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 18 January 2022
