one_reviews_text: This is a review of the Oculus Quest 2 — Advanced All-In-One Virtual Reality Headset — 128 GB.I have never used a virtual reality device before and was super eager to try it out. I have heard good things about the Oculus Quest 2 so I was really happy to get one. Happy to say it’s pretty amazing.First of all about me, I am older and although I’m fairly techie, I have never tried VR before. So as soon as I opened the box I was a little intimidated because frankly the instruction pamphlet is not all that great for a novice and the start-up foldout only gets you connected. Following the foldout was easy - now to go on and see what this puppy can do.I immediately went to the Internet and looked up various videos because at least for me, it wasn’t all that intuitive and I was having some trouble figuring out how to use the controls and access the apps and programs I wanted. Once I saw the videos, it was easy.So how do I like it? I have to say it’s pretty amazing. The headset feels okay/comfortable and you can adjust the  lens for clarity - not perfect but fine and doable. It’s easy to set up with one problem I had at the start - the tab to pull out of one of the hand controls ripped which was an issue and we had to struggle to get it out.  Without removing those tabs you cannot operate or connect the Oculus Quest 2. Again, be sure to check out settings and the various options and  check out some of the available fan videos.The only concern I have - and no stars off for this because it’s not the fault of the Oculus Quest 2 - is that it really gave me motion sickness after just 10 minutes and I felt dizzy. I have tried it out several times to no avail - I am prone to migraines and sadly, I won’t be able to use this. I have some issues even watching movies in 3D so this did not come as a great surprise to me. My husband had the same problems I did while using it, although he too was amazed by the graphics and clarity. I did give it to my son who is in 7th heaven so it all worked out great.Lastly - you have to have a Facebook account to use this which was an issue for me because I had closed out my FB account because I didn’t want it. So to use this, I opened another one under my husband’s name with full privacy mode and no other information than his name. That’s one way to get around this I guess but do know you need that FB account.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 15 September 2021
review_title: Incredible clarity; fun and also great for gamers. Just one concern about this for me.

one_reviews_text: I have tried various VR headsets, from those you have a mobile phone attached to a headset, another is the Oculus Go, which I have had the opportunity to do research for the mental health industry and also train those in the industry on the use and potential of the technology.But today I am testing the recently released 128GB version of the Oculus Quest 2, which was released by Oculus, a brand owned by Facebook.The virtual reality headset was released on October 13, 2020 as a 64GB model priced at $299 and a 128GB model for $399. On August 2021, the 128GB model dropped to $299 and the 256GB model was released for $399.The latest version featured a similar design to the original Quest while lighter in weight, updated specifications, a higher refresh rate and resolution and updated Oculus Touch controllers.So, I wanted to see for myself of how I felt about the technology and its improvements since 2019.The headset comes with a head strap, the two Oculus touch controllers each with a AA battery and a USB-C power adapter.After charging the unit, I went ahead and set my headset to my wireless connection and connected it to my Facebook account.It's important for everyone to know that it is mandatory that you MUST have a Facebook account for this device. The account is profile-based, and you can not set multiple profiles. So, those used to a console such as a PlayStation, XBOX or Nintendo Switch who are used to having multiple profiles, this is not possible. If you have several children, they can either play under your account profile or you will need to purchase each person their own headset.And then can setup your virtual environment from the currently eight offered and then get acquainted with software like First Step (which is an entertaining introduction to the how VR is with the unit and will impress those who never used VR before).You can setup your "Guardian" which you can see your space and making a ring around you, to let the unit know how much space you have for gaming, so you don't hit the wall or any thing that you have in your room.But then it's time to check out the apps available.  Most will want to try the free apps offered.  But then I was ready to purchase and test out games from numerous genres.The first game I decided to test out was one game that many people have put high in their "must-buys".So, after doing research, I wanted to test out the system completely in the following genres.   For rhythm and dance games: "Beat Saber", "Audio Trip" and "Synth Riders".  And two games from Japan, such as "Kizuna Ai - Touch the Beat!" and "Beat Arena".For shooter, I decided to try "Population One", "Pistol Whip", "Blaston" and "Larcenauts".  For sports, "Golf 5 eClub", "Top Golf with Pro Putt" and "ForeVR Bowling".  For fighting, "Thrill of the Fight!", "Ironlights: Ultimate Update" and "Holopoint".  For adventure, the three episodes of "Star Wars: Vader Immortal". For social, I tried VRchat, vTime and AltspaceVR.With the rhythm games, each of the three games provided an entertaining and fun workout.  Featuring cool music and most importantly, companies releasing inexpensive DLC music packs is a plus.    Each have a similarity in choosing skill factor and ability to select different music and go at your own pace.  Have only ten minutes to work out, then dance to three songs.But what I like is the workout aspect.  You are going to dance as you crouch or move to the left and right to avoid barriers.  And the better you get, you can set your skill higher for an even more intense workout.For the two Japanese games, "Kizuna Ai - Touch the Beat" is no doubt for the anime fans who want an easier pace and the fact that the makers put on live events (announced on Twitter on FB) to coincide with their device is a plus.  While "Beat Saber" allows you to play drums, guitar and bass and strumming or hitting the drum to the beat/symbol.  But I see the potential, for the Japanese market to really capitalize on the growth of VR as many established, may it be anime,RPG or sports games from Japan can be suitable for VR.The golfing on the Oculus Quest 2 is absolutely awesome.  I was surprised of how my swing was actually emulated quite well on the Oculus Quest 2, from driving to putting.  And the fact that you have golf enthusiasts playing and competing is a plus.  While I tested "Thrill of the Fight!" and the boxing mechanics were quite awesome.  Again, the workout involved in quick punches, jabs, etc. and the training in the gym, makes for another wonderful reason to get a VR headset.But games such as "Holopoint" is one of those games where you will need adequate space.  When purchasing a game on Oculus, you will receive a warning that the game is meant to be played in a larger setting.  Of course, a few people may guesstimate that they have adequate room and may have 5.5 feet when they game asks for 6.5 feet from all sides.  So, please do your due diligence in researching the game and how much space you need.For shooting, this is where I could only do ten minute sessions.  You have to shoot, move, crouch and prepare for intense combat that you are often in motion. If first-person shooters on a console doesn't give you motion sickness (as I play a lot), a shooter on VR is a different story.  You have to think quick, move quick and while "Pistol Whip" and "Blaston" was easier, I realized that shooting games that require a lot of movement will take awhile for me to get used to.  I tried to do an hour of "Population One" and I was nauseous right after and even the morning after.But the first game that made me love gaming on the Oculus Quest 2 was "Star Wars: Vader Immortal".  I love how the game was immersive and the first moment when you come into contact with the Empire, what a memorable VR experience.And last but not least, the chats available.  I think that as I partake in the various VR chats, many have adopted life for a few hours in the VR world to be exciting, especially during these times.  The people you meet all around the world and conversations are quite enjoyable most of the time (and yes, like real life, you can see drama especially during the discussion of politics and religion).  But for the most part, the VR social community opens up a new way of communicating much different from ZOOM and for people who have anxiety or feel awkward about their personal appearance, many have said they took up VR for that purpose.So, for the most part, the Oculus Quest 2 has managed to change the lives of many people.It's important to note that I also tested out the Oculus Air Link which allows you to hook up to the your laptop wirelessly, so you can play VR games that are installed on your PC/laptop.  And you'll need to purchase a USB-C link cable for the Oculus Quest 2 separately, if you want to transfer files and also for those who want to run code on their device.  One of the things I do is I record my gameplay and I transfer the video to my computer.And for me, it has changed my life because the inability for me to feel safe working out during this time, I like the fact that I can work out but be entertained.  For nearly two years, I have been working out indoors and to be frank, while things worked out fine for the first few months, I grew tired to the point I stopped working out because it became more routine.  But on VR, you can workout because its more immersive, you can compete solo or with others and be immersed.Unlike a console game, you are working out your muscles through full body movement.But VR also opens the possibilities for many, especially for those who may have a disability, there are games that you can partake in, as long as you can use the controllers or even hand movements and of course, see the visuals.  I also have read about athletes who have been injured and can no longer compete professionally, who have found a second life through VR, they can train and partake in competitions through games.But also for one's mental health for those who want to be more social but are not yet ready to be with a group of people, but are able to do it in the virtual world.  And I like that many mental health clinics have services to provide special programs for those that need help.Now, you probably can tell what I've wrote so far, that I'm quite positive about the headset.  But is it perfect?Now as for the hardware itself, if there is one thing I do miss, while you can add spacers to wear glasses, the Oculus Quest 2 has three settings by moving the Oculus lenses to obtain the narrowest at 58mm, the middle setting at 63mm and the widest at 68mm.  In the past, you can easily choose and  manually set a variety of ranges to suit one's vision, so if you wanted 60mm, you can't do that.I did replace the headset, you can purchase the Oculus Elite headstrap or other similar headstraps that are more padded and a better fit and are easy to adjust.I also replaced the facial interface, because I sweat a lot and so I wanted something that handles sweat much better, but if you have friends over, I can easily switch out foam with replacements, so multiple people can play and I can introduce more people to VR.  I also purchased universal disposable hygiene covers as well.I also added a skin for the headset and the Oculus Touch controllers, more for protection and I don't want staining or my device to get dirty.But I also purchase a special mat for VR gaming, so I know when I'm moving too much and I can tell when I feel the ridge of the mat that I'm moving to far that I may hit the wall, the couch or getting too close to my aquarium. Because while the Guardian on the headset will show you that you are leaving the safe zone, because you are immersed in the game, sometimes you just fail to pay attention and thus, the mat really helped out with gameplay.Overall, I feel that now is the time to get into VR.  The number of people who are becoming VR gamers and also taking part in the VR community, may it be through a social platform, competitive gaming, etc. has grown.It's changed my life to the point that I look forward to donning the headset at the end of a workday and I have to work out and visit the social community later in the evening and communicate with others.  For adults, this is a wonderful, innovative hardware to own that can be a life changer for many.But like any technology, many adults use it for competitive gaming, casual gaming and social chatting.  And as I know many parents will purchase children headsets, thinking it's another pass-the-time gaming, the problem right now is that certain VR social platforms and even certain games will have children who will talk, cuss and there are few who try to ruin one's experience or those who try to be involved in adult conversations where it's not appropriate for them to be part of.But for the most part, owning the Oculus Quest 2 has more positives than negatives.The Oculus Quest 2 is fantastic, and while not perfect, the improvement in VR technology these last few years and the growing number of things one can do in VR makes the Oculus Quest 2 one of the best investments one can make for 2021.Highly recommended!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 22 September 2021
review_title: Fantastic!  With the holiday season around the corner - A must buy!

one_reviews_text: I now own 2 Quest 2's, though one I immediately gifted. I got my first in November of 2020, and ever since have enjoyed it immensely. It's not just a gaming headset, it's a media device, it's a relaxation tool, a workout device, and of course a solid gaming headset. There's more to it than just playing games, which is why I can recommend it to so many kinds of people. Let me explain why that is.The Quest 2 is first off, a lighthouse free device. No set-up of little boxes to see the headset in the corners of the room or on the ceiling. It uses Cameras on the headset, and a virtual boundary that you draw when you start up the headset. You do have to confirm the boundary or re-draw it every time you turn it off and back on all the way, not just let it sleep, but that's a minor issue. Tracking is not as solid as a lighthouse VR like a Steam Index, HTC Vive, Etc. but very usable. There are times where it's a problem, mainly sniping in games like Hotdog's Horseshoe's and Handgrenades, but that's a minor issue. Plus many slight imperfections in tracking are being accounted for by game developers such as Anton of H3VR to make the experience with Camera tracking better for more precision with less precise tracking methods.The media playing of the Quest 2 is very good. You can pull up 3 browser screens at once surrounding you in normal Quest mode with tabs open in each one outside of the active tab. I've had no issues related to compatibility between the Quest 2 Browser and any site, especially when you can request the Mobile or Desktop version of the site if it doesn't work on one. I have not tried putting files directly onto the Quest 2 for playback, so I can't speak on that. The screen on the Quest 2 is very crisp (though not 4K by any means) to where I don't have any issue watching a movie on it with the normal resolution.Comfort wise, I think this is one of the main drawbacks of the Quest 2. The stock strap is good, I used mine for a long period, and still go back to it for certain use scenarios. However, it's not as secure as I want for movement intensive games like Beat saber, even if it won't fall off. Ever since replacing the strap, I've had less headaches with the Quest 2. It also can strain the eyes, but I personally have less issues with that than most. I've played on a Quest 2 for 10 hours straight, and my eyes felt slightly bothered. Not saying everyone can do that. They also recently added a Silicone cover to all Quest 2's or the ability to request one for your Quest 2, which feels much better than the foam alone. The foam to me felt like sandpaper after only a short period, and that cover feels like what it should have been before. Some people will have issues with the Quest 2 using a 3 position IPD, which will change how well you see the lenses. It's a "three sizes fit most" type solution to IPD adjustments. Some people will fall outside of the range of the IPD, or even in the right range won't be perfect, but I've had no issues in the default 2 position it is shipped in. It's also easy to set that position, just slide the lens left or right. Controllers feel good, and should fit most hands, they also only use 1 AA each and last for over 10 hours easily.For gaming, there's 2 different answers to how well it does. I'm breaking it up into two sections as a result. If you're not planning on using your Quest 2 for gaming, please skip this entire section.By itself: The Quest 2 is solid, though it has many limitations. It is not a replacement for a gaming computer, but it can operate many games completely stand alone. SuperHOT VR is one I personally play only on the Quest 2 by itself, and it's been out a moment. You can get many solo VR games on the Quest 2 app store, but some will have graphical downgrades over the PC versions. One example of a game doing this is Onward, a Military Sim shooter, which had to be graphically downgraded on Quest 2's to be compatible to play on the system, but still be capable of playing with true PC players. Many may also look to play VRchat on the system, while I recommend the experience, Quest users on the game are unable to see PC avatars or go to PC worlds, which is a shame. Understand that by itself, the Quest 2 is limited somewhat by it's capabilities, but many developers are designing their games around it, or for compatibility with it. It will be a good amount of time before the Quest 2 becomes an unsupported standalone system.Oculus Link: While the Quest 2 has problems running many games by itself, or have to be downgraded to deal with the processing power, it doesn't have to stay that way. Oculus and aftermarket companies have Oculus Link cables which are USB-C charging cables that are designed for high data transfer rates for a smooth experience. They are also intended to connect your computer to the headset, to use the computer's processing power to play games, rather than the Quest's. As a result, this allows you to play all PC VR games on the Quest 2. However, this hinges on your computer being able to run VR games at all, and at a smooth enough rate to make it a worthwhile experience. VR ready PC's are not cheap, but if you're already trying to play the latest intensive games at high resolution, your hardware already is likely up to the task to play in VR. Even some less powerful PC setups can be fixed to make the experience better, rendering then upscaling to the desired resolution, or other methods. This can make a game much more smooth, less taxing on the hardware running it, and more enjoyable. What you will need to run the games is far beyond the scope of this review, and you may want to consult someone who knows about computers to ask if your setup is powerful enough to run VR. Also, the Link cable needs to be secure, one tip I have is to use a strap, usually included with VR cables, and strap it to the side of the headset neat where the charge port is. This will keep the cord from dangling straight down and occasionally disconnecting the link. Also with the stock strap, run the cable through the middle of the headstrap, then to the charge port then use the individual strap, so the cable runs down your back, not your side, helps to keep you from being twisted up. One other downside is the Link does still use battery life with many setups due to the power being sent to your headset being lower than the usage, still can get many hours of play at full charge, and able to go again the next day for just as long. I don't know much about using Air Link or Virtual Desktop for wireless Link connections so, I can't comment. I tried, it didn't work very smoothly for me.Final conclusion or a TLDR: This headset is likely one of the best headsets for entering VR, for any reason. Watching movies on a big giant virtual screen can never get old to me, or meeting friends "face to face" on a game using the Link function, or hitting blocks that fly past me to a song's rhythm in beat saber to exercise a little in doors, whatever I use it for, it works, and well. It isn't the best VR headset out there, but it is the current best Standalone VR headset to date. Capacity wise, 128 GB is fine, but with too many games, you may run into storage problems, but seeing how everything on the Headset is digital, things are easily deleted and re-installed as needed. Resolution is nice, comfort is acceptable with some issues but minor, and the quality of the build is good. At no point have I ever thought I wasted my money on this, if anything, I wish I had gotten it sooner. Oh one other feature I want to mention is that due to it using cameras to see the outside world for tracking purposes, you can also look outside of VR without ever taking off the headset. Through passthrough, you can see the outside world in Black and White. Very handy feature that I believe all headsets after this one need to include. For the price, this is an easy sell, highly recommend buying this headset, and going from there. If you're looking for the best of the best VR PC headset, this isn't that, but it is a great entry level PC headset, that won't steer you wrong. Mine hasn't let me down, and shows no signs that it will.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 14 September 2021
review_title: A great headset, made better by increased capacity for no additional cost over the old 64GB model.

one_reviews_text: This is awesome. Take your gaming up a level with this! I promise, you've never used anything like it and you aren't even going to want to go back to traditional gaming systems. It's perfect for adults and kids. My 9 year old and 5 year old have no problems using it.There's a ton of games to buy and you can even watch movies!This comes already charged but you'll want to charge it as you set it up and it updates. Then, you log into your internet and Facebook and you're ready to go.The only downside is that you have to connect it to a Facebook account. I don't really like that aspect but because this is so much fun and so easy to use, I won't take off any stars.They are always uploading more games and the app is easy to use and navigate.You can also get a Chromecast so that everyone can watch what you're doing on the TV, which definitely ups the experience.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 September 2021

one_reviews_text: The Oculus Quest 2 is undoubtedly the best entry into VR for the price of $299. You get a sharp display and powerful enough hardware to be truly immersed. The headset doesn't require a PC so you can take it anywhere with you. It's like carrying a 80in TV with you wherever you go. There is a ton of content to keep you entertained for days. My main uses are watching my shows on the Oculus while my wife is watching her shows on the TV and gaming through Steam VR. There is a new silicone wrap for the headset included in the box to address the issues that people were having with the foam around the headset.TECH- The basic set comes with the Quest 2 headset and 2 hand controllers- The screen is sharp with 1832 x 1920 resolution per eye. You can still see the "screen door" effect but it is minimal.- 72 Hz default refresh rate but can be set all the way up to 120Hz. The downside is higher power usage and faster battery drain.- USB-C port on side to connect to PC through Oculus Link to access SteamVR- AirLink feature works well if you have a WIFI6 5GHz with a solid connectionERGONOMICS- The headset itself is front-heavy. You can adjust the horizontal strap to get a tighter fit and the vertical strap to align the headset to your eyes. I didn't get tired of wearing the headset but it does fog up on occasion when you engage in strenuous activity.- The controllers are lightweight and comfortable. The buttons are ergonomically positioned and very responsive. The tracking was near instantaneous, never once did I feel a lag.APP STORE- Many VR apps and games, but you will need to hook up Oculus Link to gain access to what I consider the premier titles on SteamVR.- Netflix, Amazon, Youtube, Showtime, ESPN, MLB are represented here. The majority of these apps are just "theater" apps, where you are sitting on a couch and there is a screen in front of you where you can sometimes change the size. More content providers need to get their wares on this store, there should be no excuses.PROS- Price is $299 for 128GB and entry into the world of VR. Nothing else comes close to the Quest 2 specs and price.- Very portable entertainment center to take anywhere with you. Effectively replaces a game console, a large screen television and your streaming device.- You can use your hands in place of controllers, the gestures are intuitive but the hand tracking needs a little more work to be more accurate.CONS- Facebook requirement is a deal-breaking decision for some. Having an Oculus account serves the same social networking purpose to link users but Facebook wants to tap into your entire social network. Luckily you can set your privacy settings now, but for how long is anyone's guess.- Missing many apps in its ecosystem to make this a no-brainer purchase.- Requires Oculus Link and high end PC to tap into the best titles in VR gaming- Eyeglass wearers might find the headset to be restricting
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 8 September 2021
review_title: Unquestionably the best VR headset for the money

one_reviews_text: I've had the Oculus Quest 2 for a couple months now, and I really like what I've seen. It offers a highly immersive and fun little escape. I'm not much of a gamer anymore, so I haven't played any of the hardcore games that the Oculus Quest 2 offers. But what I have done, is play A LOT of the PokerStars VR game! That game is free and a lot of fun.Some drawbacks that I've ran into with this system is that it's directly linked to your facebook account. Without an account, you can't do anything. Also, when facebook's servers went down a few weeks ago, the Oculus Quest 2 went down with it. There's the battery life too, which isn't that great. Usually after 1-2 hours of gameplay, the Oculus Quest 2 needs to be charged. Lastly, my wife can not use this system because only after a few minutes it will cause her to experience nausea, so just a heads up with that!All and all, I really like this console and even though I haven't used it to it's fullest potential, I can definitely see myself playing this thing for quite a while. I also believe that the tech will be a game changer in the future.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 23 November 2021

one_reviews_text: I had tried a friend's Oculus Quest a couple of years ago and was really excited about the opportunity to own one myself. While we can geek out on all the capabilities, processing speed, and resolution the magical part is that quickly after putting on the headset your brain takes over and you just accept the new reality. That said, these really are a pretty amazing piece of hardware with essentially a whole computer you can wear on your head.FaceBook did a keynote not long ago where they talked about the fact that they are doubling down on virtual reality as a key part of the "metaverse". The good news is that if there was any question about if Oculus was going to have support from FaceBook their parent company they have made it clear that under the new company name "Meta", Virtual Reality is a big part of their vision. They also answered some questions about the future or the product with some ideas like at a future date you will be able to use Oculus without a Facebook account and you'll be able to separate your business virtual reality from your personal one.For playing games, the Quest is an amazingly immersive experience and I love that it is active. I regularly build up a sweat playing games on the Quest.The one experience I feel like the Quest isn't quite there yet is media consumption. It is awesome that there are apps like Hulu and Netflix on Quest and the idea of having a virtual screen the size of a movie theater is incredible. If you are in a situation where you don't have access to a TV, it would be a great way to consume media. For most people, it is likely that they are using their Quest in the same room as their television and you'll have a better picture just watching your TV than using the quest.Overall very happy with the "Oculus Quest 2 — Advanced All-In-One Virtual Reality Headset — 128 GB". It is a great experience and definitely the future of not just gaming but many asp[ects of life.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 December 2021

one_reviews_text: If you've never tried VR before THIS is the way to start!The Quest 2 is an amazing addition to the library of VR options available these days. First off the device itselfIts VERY lightweight! When I got the box I was curious if it actually had a VR unit in it. It did obviously! The device is very modest in size and weight. Don't let that fool you, this is a very powerful machineSetup is quite easy. Most will require an update and depending your internet this could take awhile. Also be aware there is a required facebook account (which is obviously free) which some complain about but personally I don't see why all the gripe since its a device designed by facebook.There are several options of customizations for this. From straps to face covers etc, making you're quest easily able to fit your needs.Graphics are superb, competing with high end very expensive units. The resolution and refresh rate is even better than some high end pc VR units!Best part is the quest 2 can easily run WITH your PC. An excellent feature enabling you to (with some additional software) play games that are PC based, ON your quest 2 with the higher refresh rates. THIS is awesome because with again, the right software you can play wirelessly, making VR VERY immersive!Given this DOES require a high end PC and wifi connection.Gaming library is expanding nearly everyday! Some games are just gimicky like alot of vr titles these days but several high end games are coming out. I wont mention any but they are easily researchable , and strongly suggest checking out the libraries available.Battery life is 'ok' at roughly 2 hrs of gaming, but several options available allow increasing that, from battery pack addons to corded play.Durability is okay, just obviously don't treat it rough cause it IS a high tech machine.Onboard sensors are the best part for you don't need any external sensory devices like other VR devices out there so its purely a true standalone device. Easy to just pick up and play at your convenience.Also built in with a guardian feature which allows you to set boundaries preventing you from destroying furniture and or things like your TV depending where you play LOL.The controllers are VERY comfortable! And the battery life is amazingly epic. The power stayed at 100% for days of playing before it started dropping. Compared to other devices which batteries may last a few days I could see these puppies lasting weeks if not longer. They are very sensitive controllers and the quest 2 now features 'hand recognition' so with some apps and games you don't even need controllers!If you never have tried VR I strongly suggest starting with this hardware. Its not very expensive but very high end on the spectrum, and it will be a good investment assuming you are into gaming and VR gaming.Seriously check this out if interested in VR. Whether new or looking to check out new hardware, totally worth it and one of the best priced hardware's I've seen.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 4 October 2021
review_title: Excellent entertainment value! Whole new worlds exist for the taking!

one_reviews_text: This is the new Oculus Quest 2, which is basically exactly the same as the older Quest except that it comes with half the memory, 128Gb of inbuilt storage rather than 256Gb and is priced $100 cheaper than the 256Gb version.The Quest 2 is the perfect entry level headset to find out whether or not you like the VR world.  Some people don't  like VR for various reasons including vertigo and the feeling of getting sick, neck pain as the headsets are fairly heavy on your head etc.  Other people love it and spend hours on it.For your money your will get the headset itself, a fairly comfortable elastic strap to attach it to your head, two controllers and a charging cable.  Setup is fairly simple. You connect it to your phone using bluetooth and just follow the prompts.  You will need a Facebook account to tie it to and this puts some people off (I understand why) but the majority of people already have a facebook account anyway.The Quest 2 has 2 1832x1920 LCD screens. Not quite 4K but a higher resolution than HD.  For the money this isn't bad, especially considering the higher resolution Rift S is double the price.  The eye pieces are slightly adjustable to 3 different positions, dependent upon the size of your head and space between your eyes.  One great thing about the LCD display is that you can adjust the frame rate.  I have mine set to 72Hz which I feel is much smoother than default 60Hz setting and this makes me much less prone to feeling sick.  There is also a 90Hz refresh rate however for PC gaming that is too high unless you have a seriously beefy graphics card.  Note however that you do not need a PC to use this.The headset also has 3D capable audio built directly into the headset.  The sound quality is OK but nothing outstanding. As such a lot of people also wear headphones when using the Quest 2 and there is a built in 3.5mm audio port to hook your headphones into.  Personally, the sound is good enough for me and I prefer using it without the added weight of a pair of headphones.The headset is quite heavy and although the soft elastic strap that comes with it is adequate, I would highly recommend purchasing one of the Elite, hard backed straps that you can find on amazon. These do make a lot of difference in distributing the weight, making wearing the headset much more comfortable and you can wear it for longer.The Quest 2 has hundreds of apps and games available for it, from watching netflix and shooting games to fitness and boxing games.  Even games such as boxing do help you to get in shape as you quickly find yourself ducking and weaving as well as throwing punches as you get immersed in the gameplay.  These games are stored in the 128Gb of memory in the headset and aren't that large so even with 128Gb you should have plenty of room for a number of games and apps.You can also attach your headset to your PC and play VR games on your PC.  To do this you will need to buy an Oculus cable. The official one comes in at $80 which is very pricey.  You can find third party cables that do the exact same thing for much less.  I love to play DCS and Flight Simulator 2020 on my PC with the Quest.  The immersion takes it to a whole other level, however in order to do so you will also need a fairly beefy PC to handle the graphics.  My PC is a couple of years old, so its not powerful enough to turn up all the textures in Flight Sim to Ultra, but it is good enough to play with reasonably high definition.  Honestly this is the main use I have for the Quest 2.  At somepoint I will probably upgrade to the Rift S, but a new PC is in order before that.So if your interested in dabbling with VR or don't have the budget to buy the Rift S then I would highly recommend the Quest 2.  This 128Gb version, coming in at just $300 is well worth the money and I very highly recommend it.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 1 October 2021
review_title: A superb entry to the world of VR

one_reviews_text: I have been playing with this for a little less than three weeks now (so that I could deliver the most thorough and accurate review possible). And, overall, I am really pleased. Now, this is not my first experience with the Oculus: I did have the first gen one. And, a lot has changed for the better (which is truly impressive).Foremost, this is way lighter than the first gen Oculus (which is great). And, the battery here has a longer life as well (which means more play-time without a break for a charge ... and I love that).Now, unlike the first version, the "focus range" here has preset numbers instead of the range that was available in the first gen. So, there are larger increments which may mean very slightly less overall clarity.This is truly so much more comfortable than the first gen version. The first one was very front-heavy (which we would sometimes counterbalance with a little weight on the back). Here, you don't need any mods at all: it has great balance. (And that is the absolute best!)Overall, this has great hand-tracking which allows you to operate the Oculus without any controllers at all. And, that will always amaze me!Beat Saber looks great, the game is great, and there is even a 360 mode which this Quest excels at (since there are no wires unlike the Valve Index).Likewise, there are so many free videos that you can enjoy! So, much can be watched without further investment of money (which is great for those with kids who are always seeking something new). And, many of these freebies are educational: you can learn about history, take tours of various landmarks, explore overhead views of cities, etc. You can even have a 360 experience on the moon! It's very cool!You can add Oculus friends and play games with them (which is really great for those who are maintaining their "personal bubbles" right now). Love that!In sum, it is 100% worth upgrading from the first gen version to this one. It's a fantastic starting point for VR! Very highly recommended!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 September 2021

one_reviews_text:
As I've already been enjoying virtual reality games and apps since 2019 with my Oculus Rift S headset, picking up the Oculus Quest 2 was a no-brainer for me. Unlike the Rift S, which requires a wired connection to a beefy gaming PC, the Quest 2 has no such requirements and all I needed was my smartphone to set up the Quest 2 and quickly get started playing. Yay to no more twisted and tangled up wire that I have to unwind once in a while to remove the annoying kinks. 👍As a result of being freed from wires, I can enjoy my games in more environments and I no longer have to pack as much stuff when taking it to friends' houses; carrying a 10-lb gaming laptop and its heavy charger is no fun.Being free from a powered PC, of course, means a shorter continuous playtime since you're limited by the built-in battery size and life. There is a way, however, to extend your playtime through a device such as the 
X-super Home Adjustable Elite Strap with Battery Bracket
 - by strapping on a powerbank to the strap, game time can be extended for a couple more hours. Such a setup adds some weight but I consider it a worthy trade-off.My favorite VR game is Beat Saber and I was disappointed to find out that I had to purchase it again ($29.99). Due to the great exercise it offers, though, I purchased the game again, and playing it on the Quest 2 is just as fun and accurate as playing on the Rift S.Unlike my Rift S, the Quest 2 came with a silicone cover inside the box which was a pleasant surprise.Just like the Rift S, the speakers on the Quest 2 are so-so. I recommend watching shows & playing games with some quality headphones jacked in to up the feeling of immersiveness.At $299.00 (as of 2021-09-15), the Quest 2 is priced like a regular game console (e.g., Nintendo Switch) and I think it's fairly priced for all the high-tech VR you can experience and a library of quality and fun titles that are available. It's a 5-Star Win!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 September 2021

one_reviews_text: I have heard a lot about virtual reality devices but never got a chance to experience what VR was and decided to give the Oculus Quest 2 a try.The device itself is nicely made but very intriguing. It is a pretty big unit that sits right in front of the eye, it is not too heavy but definitely carries some weight but is tightly secured thanks to the strap.The set up was quite easy as all I had to do was download an app on the phone which then communicate with the Oculus.I get motion sick very easily and was a bit worried I would not last long with the device but the library of apps and games is extensive and contains many options that are not zero gravity and are ground based.I started with the virtual visits of places around the world and I have to admit that it was an amazing experience as I felt that I was really visiting the country. I also tried a few games and it is definitely a huge difference over the console games I am used to as it really made me feel that I was inside the game.All in all, I have to say that I found the Oculus fantastic, I never thought that it would be this realistic.  I am glad I finally got a chance to own one and it goes with say that the Oculus Quest 2 gets a perfect rating from me.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 14 September 2021

one_reviews_text: I honestly didn't know if I'd even like VR, but the Oculus Quest 2 and the game Beat Saber (which you need to purchase separately) changed all that. I never thought of VR as an ideal place to get a workout. Beat Saber, which is a must purchase for the Oculus, gets my blood flowing and body sweating more than working out at the gym. The headset comes with an optional silicone covering which is very helpful as I can't believe just how much I sweat using this thing. I also purchased The Thrill of The Fight, which is one of the toughest and best boxing games i've ever played. Beyond games, I've enjoyed exploring VR worlds on AtlspaceVR, Facebook's Horizon's and VR Chat.I really like how the Oculus Quest 2 defines the playspace, there are options for both a fixed guardian and a custom guardian so you can define your play space. They also have the option of adding your couch and computer, so you can add both into your home VR Space.The Quest 2 has held up pretty well with one notable exception, the wrist straps aren't awesome. This can be easily remedied with an aftermarket controller wrap, which can add a much helpful ant-throw palm strap, which I greatly prefer.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 12 October 2021
review_title: I'm Surprised At How Much I Love The Oculus Quest 2

one_reviews_text: I love new technologies and it's been awhile since I've been watching VR tech.I've tried the original Quest from a friend and I was impressed with the immersive experience you get whether you're watching or gaming.Now with this Quest 2, the resolution is simply much better magnifying the immersive experience one gets on a VR headsetSetupI'm wearing a glass but I found that I don't need to wear one to use the Quest 2. My friend who wears a glass said it's still comfy to him while wearing the set.Initial setup is pretty easy. The 2 controllers are already connected and it asks to adjust the lens as needed.Account sign on - Many people (including me) are turned off of the way Oculus requires an FB account to log in. For me and I think for most, it's a privacy issue and FB is not that known to be an advocate of that. What I did, is I created a separate fresh FB account and that's what I used to log in to Quest 2. So far so good.Here's my favorite games that I play: • Super Hot • Beat Saber • Eleven Table Tennis • Vader Immortal 1-3I occasionally browse youtube VR contents, watch Netflix, HBO Max moviesWatching Youtube in VR is a different level of experience.Optionally, you have an option to connect this to a VR-ready PC to take advantage of the vast PCVR games only available to PCs.This allows you to play much more selection of games via PC. There are 2 ways to connect, one is wired via Oculus Link cable (purchased separately) and another is wirelessly through Virtual Desktop app from Oculus store. There's a number of sites discussing the how and the requirements, just google or search Youtube.I'm able to play Star Wars Squadrons, Half Life: Alyx, Powerbeats.In case you're not aware of the news that some users reported having a rash, the box already came with Quest 2 silicone cover. I've read in the news that the incidents only happen to a very small percentage and I personally have no issue using the default face plate and I've used it for like 30mins or so per session.In my opinion, it's kinda icky to use the default face plate if you're trying to use it for extended sessions especially with games like BeatSaber or Powerbeats where you'll be sweating a lot. The default one is made of I think high quality foam that can absorb sweat. I end up using the included rubber face plate that's easy to wipe with water/alcohol every after session for better hygiene.Mixed reality VRI've discovered this awesome feature just recently. It means you can put yourself inside a game and it doesn't need a green screen! There are more and more games being added. You can search Liv and mixed reality in Youtube for the how to videos.Overall I'm happy with Oculus Quest 2. Technologies change every time and I think it's the right time to jump on experiencing VR whether for workout, gaming, watching movies, explore different places virtually. Life is short. The immersive experience is just worth it. =)
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 20 September 2021

one_reviews_text: Its really really fun.  Tough to get set up because you need a facebook account to get an oculus account to get the occulus app to get the...next...next...next.  But, once it is going, its addictive, unless it makes you motion sick, which is very possible.  I was blown away by the graphics, expecting pixelated stuff from years ago, but nope.  I got the VR Hot game, and its a good workout, just make room so you dont accidentally punch people.  The game Moss was amazing, kinda short, but great and you can play it sitting down.  For the kids, Acron!  OMG its so fun.  Because the littel kids hands cant reach all the triggers at once, most games are difficult, but Acron only needs the one trigger button, so we all take turns, and it is co-op with everyone else who can use the cell phone or tablet app.  If you have kids 6 and up, I strongly suggest that one.  Battery life is pretty good, but get a back up stand alone battery for long runs if you dont want to be tethered to the charger.  Fits nice and feels good on the head.  Dont use the rubber 'eyeglasses' thing unless you need to, it locks in moisture and can fog things up and heat them up.  All in all, efverything you need is in the nice box, you can even store it in there, its that nice.  Im really happy with this.  We play at least once a week. And yes, you can cast to most devices so people can watch what you are seeing.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 20 December 2021
review_title: Great but needs Facebook, tough for little hands

one_reviews_text: I really enjoyed and still am playing with the oculus, specially with high res latest content but FB (meta) track record is not promising▶ Quality & DesignNice slice white finish, really well made and surprisingly light. The remotes are also ergonomically made and compliment the design of the headset. The straps on the head set are comfortable and easy to adjust▶ SetupAs you probably aware you will need a FB account. It's pretty useless without one, so if you get kicked out or banned from FB and unable to come back you get yourself a nice piece of nothingness... isn't that greatOn the other hand the setup was pretty seamless and fairly quick. The tutorial is helpful to get the know the system and its limitations. It's nice that you can set a safe zone in your view so you wont hit any furniture or other obstacles▶ UsageHigh res stuff look pretty awesome and you probably won't get dizzy or nausea but lower res content is no fun and motion will hit your head and limit your usage as you quickly get disorientated. The remotes are very responsive and the tracking and visualization on your headset works great with minimal lag✅ Pros: Newer content, comfortable, easy to use❌ Cons: Fb account needed, lots of old lower res contentOverall, if you don't mind been bound to FB this is a really great piece to technology
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 9 December 2021
review_title: Really amazing device but FB entanglement is questionable

one_reviews_text: Appearance:Sleek headset that can adjust to your head size.  The handheld wands  blend with the appearance of the headset.Assembly:This is plug and play.  Take it out of the box and start exploring!Installation:Only downside is that you have to use a Facebook account to log onto the Quest 2.  That is the only way this will work.  You'll also get a good number of software/firmware updates for the unit, so be prepared to wait a little bit after turning it on for the first time.  It is worth the wait though!  Pull on the headset, adjust the straps to your liking and adjust the lenses to move slightly in or out depending on how your eyes are positioned on your face.Thoughts:Man, this thing is awesome!  The graphics are fantastic and you can truly get lost in the environments.  Even the Oculus lobby is breathtaking.  Software setup is super easy.  You set your physical playzone up and the headset will track how close or how far you are from the edges.  There is also passthrough which will allow you to see the physical space in front of you, albeit from an alternate universe-type view.It's a fantastic piece for gaming, exploring (check out the ISS from the inside!), and almost anything else you can think of.  Personally, we play a lot of Beat Saber in this and it is just so much fun.  The games are fairly simple to browse, the app store could use some user experience work, but it's definitely good enough.It does get a bit warm inside the face area, so if you're playing a very physical game, be prepared for some sweat.  It might be a good idea to invest in a face mask protector so the foam portion isn't getting all wet.Overall:I love this system.  I would happily buy it again
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 26 September 2021
review_title: Yes! Fun and Exciting VR Environment!

one_reviews_text: I want to start with the issue I had with the store. Before I got this headset, I had an Oculus Rift (original generation) and in the PC store, I purchased multiple games. When I got this headset, I thought that those purchases would transfer over, but unfortunately, I was mistaken. It turns out that certain games require you to re-purchase games for the Quest store, even if you already bought them through the Rift store. Now, I was informed that developers need to specifically engineer their game to the lower-performance platform, but as a consumer, it doesn't feel good to have to re-buy a game just because it's on a different platform. I thought they would at least offer a discount on the game if it was already purchased through the other store, but apparently not. There is a way around this by using the Quest Link (or Air Link) to basically play off the PC you would usually use but with the upgraded headset and inside-out tracking, which is what I ended up using for games I had already purchased on Rift.Store issues aside, this headset is so much better than VR used to be in the early days. The ability to play without wires or backpack PCs is amazing and it's hard to imagine going back! Especially with the workout apps, or full-room movement apps, no wires is the only way to play and feel fully immersed. The screen-door effect is also very reduced when compared to the Rift. Air Link is still in Early Access, so it doesn't work without issue, but when it works, it's a great way to get the full graphics processing power of a PC without any of the wires, tethers, or tracking system setup that both the Rift and Valve Index require. Of course, there are some trade-offs, but overall, I am very happy with this headset.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 6 September 2021
review_title: Fun and a good workout. A little disappointed with the store though.

one_reviews_text: I'll start by saying that my only negative is the fit. It's really hard to get a decent fit, so the words aren't blurred at all. Could just be my head shape. It does have adjusters for the width and length, as well as the eye glass part can move inward or outward.Super easy to connect and get started. Does NOT have any preloaded games, you have to buy them separately, but there are a few samples on there. We bough beat sabers with an expansion pack and a roller coaster shooting game.Note, if you are prone to motion sickness, certain games you will not be able to play....I can't stomach the rollercoaster one, but beat sabers is fine.Volume is great. Can connect to our computer screen, so others can see what you see.So far, no issues at all.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 23 September 2021

one_reviews_text: Oculus Quest 2 — Advanced All-In-One Virtual Reality Headset — 128 GBYou are required to have a fb account to useWill stand up to rougher children using and playingIf you do not shut completely off it will be a constant battery hog trying to constantly do updatesHold side power button down until the headset shuts down completelyYou have to manually set to new 90hrtz refresh rateIf planning to be a heavy user it for family gaming I suggest a battery packThe battery life just isn’t that great especially if doing heavy gamingExpect two hours maximum battery life with more like hour and a half typicallyYou can enable shortcut to side tap to look through the cameras to see outside camera viewHand tracking feature now included ( nice feature to use when watching videos)You can now change background and boundary colorYou can no now pair external Bluetooth headphonesExpect this to be the gift that keeps giving your money awayAs in you will be wanting to purchase games frequentlySeriously thought my entire family loves the oculus quest 2 and has created a new favorite past time in my home wether playing it or watching others while playing
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 19 September 2021

one_reviews_text: I got the 128gb version of the Quest 2 and I absolutely love it. I used to have the Oculus Rift but ended up selling it because I no longer had a good room to set it up in with all the sensors, cords, and my PC. With the Oculus Quest 2 I no longer have these issues and can use the headset anywhere in my house (that has enough room) without worrying about where to setup the sensors and PC. The picture quality is good and I had no issues setting it up on my first use. It is pretty neat that you can connect it with your phone to show others what you are viewing within the VR headset. Overall the quality of the headset is great and it is so much easier to setup than the Oculus Rift.Pros:Wire FreeGreat trackingGood quality displayBuilt in audio is pretty good (and you have the ability to connect your own headphones)Good amount of games to choose fromAbility to connect to a PC to play more demanding gamesCons:Headset could distribute weight of the headset better (better options can be purchased)Not all previously purchased Oculus Rift games can be played on the Quest (a lot of them transfer over, but not all can be played unless you have the cable to connect it to a PC)Battery life isn't great for longer play sessions
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 9 September 2021
review_title: All in one VR Headset - FUN!

one_reviews_text: A lot of my friends have been raving about the Oculus and how it's a must have item during quarantine. After having owned one and playing it a couple of times a week, I agree. This is a great product if you’re interested in exploring the VR world.Pros:Set up is super easy and quick, you don’t need to be tech savvyYou can easily connect with other friends that have an OculusThe user interface is easy to navigateThe actual system is very well builtLarge game library and they’re affordableCons:Not the most comfortable thing if you wear glassesInstalling the glasses spacer isn’t really easy. I’d recommend watching a youtube video to make sure you’re not removing a part that shouldn’t be removed.Headstrap isn’t the most comfortable
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 October 2021
review_title: VR is going to be the next takeover

one_reviews_text: This is my second quest 2 headset. I would recommend getting a 3rd party replacement headstrap with a battery pack holder. I think this is the best bang for your buck headset. It can operating independently with phone like graphics, or hook up to a PC. Overall Facebook keeps on adding new features, I like the use without the controllers.I had to go to a few hardware resets setting up different accounts with app sharing, but it was all working in the end. There is a limit of sharing of apps to only 1 headset, and the app owner must have the main account. The owner of the apps must use the other headset.  But playing cook out or mini golf is much more entertaining with a partner!
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 28 September 2021

one_reviews_text: This is an amazing headset, and a real leap from the last generation set. I'm seeing improvement in all the little things, resolution, peripheral vision. I'm someone who experiences some motion sickness using VR. It is still there, but there is a small improvement in that as well, likely due to the more seamless experience this headset is providing. Really great.
review_date: Reviewed in the United States on 15 September 2021

one_reviews_text: This VR headset is light weight but can be somewhat uncomfortable after extended wear.  Everything works well and I don't experience much latency.  This device is a good way to immerse yourself in the VR world to take a break from the harsh reality.My main concerned is the FB requirement.  It is rather terrifying to me how much of my personal data these big tech companies own and what they plan to do with that.  It is frustrating that they leverage their size to force you to provide more and more personal information.
